bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to J.L. Byrd, June 20, 1923

div1.p: Carter requests information on mosquitos in Colon.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to J.L. Byrd, June 20, 1923
div1.opener:
--------- F. F. Russell,
M. M. C.
N. H. B.
Flight of A.
/LC
----------
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
June 20, 1923.
Dr. J. L. Byrd,
Health Officer of Cristobal and Colon,
Cristobal P. O., C. Z.
Dear Doctor Byrd:
div1.p:
I have just seen, in the Panama Star and Herald the account of
the great flight of Anopleles that you had in Colon some years ago
(1918 and 1919, as I recollect). I had heard of this before, from
Richardson or Pickett, when in Peru and it is rather late to be
asking you about it now.

I believe these mosquitoes were traced to a breeding place some
two miles distant across Manzanillo Bay and what I wish to ask you
is this:

Was their flight associated with any great increase of malaria
in Colon? The reason I ask is that in most of the very long flights
recorded the report has been to the contrary. There was no increase
of malaria noted from the great and prolonged flight at Gatun--in
1912 as I recollect it. Practically the same thing is noted in two
flights in the Dutch East Indies, one by van Bremen and one by the
Smwellengburgsergers and the same implication is made by Sella at Fiumecino in Italy
in that he finds that malaria is conveyed a far less distance than
than
2
his Anopheles travelled.

The findings noted above, if general, may be explicable by not-
ing that malaria is only conveyable by feedings after the first one:
In Panama Darling's findings were that it took about days as a mini-
mum after infection before the Anopheles became infective to man.
The first blood meal is necessary for ovaposition, the second is not,
and it is suggested that Anopheles--like most other of the more pri-
mitive organisms--will do far more to perpetuate the species than for
any other purpose--that is, they might make an excessive flight to
get blood for ovaposition: return to their breeding places and de-
posit eggs and might not--say two weeks after the first flight--re-
peat their long journey.

A distinction has thus been made between the flight for ova-
position and the contaminative flight.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
